description.text:
Dog Tag with your name

I have been printing these for family and friends for years now, I actually use this print to check my printer settings and scaling.

I enclose some of the names I have printed so far, if you would like your name to appear in this design please send me a tip and give me a shout out in the post below. I must admit I do not have a lot of free time for myself but I will try to check this website every week and post up your requests when I can.

Also for best results keep the name short i.e. Abigail is better printed as ABI – Thomas as TOM – Stephen as STEVE you get the picture, keep them short and simple. If you would rather lower case just let me know otherwise I will publish in UPPERCASE.

Because Ringoid was 1st to like I have designed his for free

description.text:
This is a prototyping board designed for making patterns for NeoPixel devices.

I'm working on a project using a full strip of NeoPixels, but I wanted a smaller prototyping kit so i didn't have to mess with an entire strip just to work on some patterns. This board includes mounts for an Arduino Uno, a Adafruit NeoPixel stick, and a mini breadboard to hold a capacitor and provide tie-in points for a secondary power supply.

NOTE: If you're running all pixels at full brightness you may exceed the power limits of the Arduino board. Be sure to use a secondary power supply if you need one, or if you're unsure.

There are four designs available:

  • Original
  • Original with Mounting Holes
  • No Breadboard
  • No Breadboard with Mounting Holes

The "no breadboard" version is useful if you're using a prototyping shield or if you want to link your NeoPixel project to a larger breadboard. Both the original and no breadboard versions have mounting hole options if you want to attach the protoboard to another board or project.

You will need 4 M3 bolts and 2 M2 bolts to attach the Arduino and NeoPixel stick, respectively. You can use a tap but the bolts should be able to form their own threads.

The mounting hole spacing is 120x65mm for the original version and 80x65mm for the no breadboard version.

Let me know if you have any questions and if you do end up making this, send me a message! I'd love to see what you create.

• Arduino Uno
  • Mini Breadboard
  • Adafruit NeoPixel Stick
  • 1 1000µF Capacitor
  • Hookup Wire (Solid)
  • 4 M3-6 Bolts
  • 2 M2-6 Bolts

title: Deltaprintr Filament Guide for Extended Extruder Arm

description.text:
This is for the XL kickstarter Deltaprintr or the standard size kickstarter printer with the optional extended extruder arm mount.

In my attempt to remove the tower wobble I have removed the filament from atop the printer and put it on a turntable on the same surface as the printer sits.

I designed this filament guide to simply push onto the laser cut plywood and guide the filament to the extruder while the spool sits way low and off the printer.

PLA, 0.2mm layer height, 20% fill, print with brim as the cylindrical guide's lower surface is very narrow, and support for arch if you have inadequate cooling.

Refinery miniature

I own a CG-5-GT equatoral mount and everytime I have to polar align the mount, I have to knee on the floor, hold the tripod with one hand and use the other to point a red flahlight into the polar scope. All this process is pretty unconfortable. Because I have no permanent observatory, I have to set up the mount every time I want to observe.

I have tested it and works great! I can now do the polar alignment in a much more confortable way.

description.text:
This is a phone mount for a Bluetooth micro-keyboard. I haven't seen any other mounts like this that rigidly hold the phone clamped to the board. The rigid connection is important while on a plane or other mass transit because you can use the phone and keyboard during take off and landing or other bumpy sections. It can be positioned on a flat surface or set on your knees. Parts were printed on a Zortrax M200.

Commercial components:

  • Keyboard ($20): https://www.amazon.com/gp/aw/d/B00BKW2410/
  • Phone clip ($4): https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00CR74FLO/

This is the third version of these that I've made because keyboards keep being discontinued. Hopefully they'll keep making that version for awhile. If you have another keyboard you want a mount made for I might be able to be convinced to rev the design again.

comments.text: You could use Igus filament for the bearings and make them thinner, shorter, just put two on each side in the housing close to the belt and just one in a shorter housing on the other smooth rod side.  This filament prints quite easily and produces good bearings. I did some in various shapes and they work better than the Chinese LM on regular SS rods.  No need for messy lubrication, silent, reduce vibration too.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: Hello
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
It is a matter of proper alignment and smooth rod play in the bearing. You have to use a reamer to get the correct ID and ream in one go.
Playing with the shape of the "fins" for ex. curl them will just add elasticity and by allowing some tension indeed it will reduce the "wiggle" but better make things fit ! It is also what you get with 4 bearings, they are under tension and therefore reduce the wiggle. It is in fact an over constrained assembly. Quality ball and roller bearings based systems can and are often preloaded to reduce play but with bushings you better aim for the proper minimal play from the start. Otherwise friction becomes excessive. Note that if it doesn't seize, it will wear out and end up with the correct size or be destroyed :) . This is called break in.
comments.author: gameoffuture

comments.text: Yes, I agree. The friction without load and the friction with load are different as well. These printed bushings are not as smooth as the cheap linear bearings when there is no load on them, but once the load is added they are really smooth. My main purpose for this was to reduce the total weight of the carriage and it has worked. I'm sure it can be refined a lot more and if one spends money could obtain much better bushing or linear bearings and tracks, but this is what's most accessible for me at the moment. If I were to buy all parts myself instead of using the Prusa i3 kit I may spend some more money and get proper rails and bearings instead.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: Yes, I agree. The friction without load and the friction with load are different as well. These printed bushings are not as smooth as the cheap linear bearings when there is no load on them, but once the load is added they are really smooth. My main purpose for this was to reduce the total weight of the carriage and it has worked. I'm sure it can be refined a lot more and if one spends money could obtain much better bushing or linear bearings and tracks, but this is what's most accessible for me at the moment. If I were to buy all parts myself instead of using the Prusa i3 kit I may spend some more money and get proper rails and bearings instead.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
My goal were the same, reduce mass and play. My Prusa X carriage is about 250g including high torque fast extruder and 270° capable hot end.
As an added challenge I try to use my own designed parts using cheap but well selected components. A 3D printer is not a CNC !
comments.author: gameoffuture

comments.text: That's sounds good. I needed a bit better quality and speed from my 3D printer, and it was beyond what Prusa i3 could possibly provide. With this machine my print speed is usually set to 50mm/s for high quality prints, and it delivers much better quality prints than my Prusa i3 could do with a lot less ripple in the corners. If I print at 75mm/s or more the ripples start to show, but they are less severe than the Prusa printing at 30mm/s. I'm also using the printer to design mechanical parts and enclosures so it helps not having to post-process the prints to make the parts fit. CoreXY seems to fit my requirements quite well and it is not expensive. It only needed some aluminum extrudes and some bearings and belt. Almost everything else is from the Prusa. I also have two machines so of this does not work out and breaks I still have backup printer, so I can afford to experiment on one machine at a time.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: Since I modified, in fact only the frame is left, my Geetech Al Prusa, can print decent quality at 2 times (200%) the default speed and for prototype 300%, the max possible. Far better than the first prints I kept.  But for big parts, the  table moving in the Y axis is the killer.
comments.author: gameoffuture

description.text:
After I got a 3D printer, I had thought about doing a big project. Since I love halloween and Monster Hunter there is nothing better project than making the most awesome looking weapon in the game. I spent almost 5 hours in blender to model this, and around 2 weeks to 3D print it and assemble it. The only thing that is not 3D printed is the stick i used as handle. I got this from my neighbour.

Now you can all get yourself a dark scythe and go and hunt some wyverns! Have a happy halloween!

Interested in monster hunter? Visit the monster hunter group for discussion and sharing ideas with other monster hunter fans. http://www.thingiverse.com/groups/monster-hunter/topics

Printer:

Wanhao duplicator 4

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.4 mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

speed: 20 mm/s
shells: 3

I scaled all the pieces 10000 times.

I glued all the pieces with epoxy. This is very hard and strong glue that holds the pieces together pretty good. There was a piece that the support fell of. This piece was fixed using a gluegun. It is not very visible after i painted it. I painted the model with metalic grey spraypaint and then painted the rest of the details with acrylic paint. I also filled in some parts where it was a scale difference (like between the printed shaft attachment part and the wood shaft) with some filler to make it look and work better.

I modeled the whole thing from the bottom in Blender. First I modeled the base mesh and then sculpted the details using a tablet. When i was satisfied with the result, I sliced it in pieces with blenders boolean modifier and a cube. I made the hole in the shaft part after i knew the diameter of the shaft. If you are going to print this yourself, you may change the diameter using a modeling software. description.text:
This is a threaded part that mates to many common bottles. If, like me, you have a neurosis that means you cannot stand wasting that last little bit of liquid in a bottle of shampoo or soap, you can use this to easily transfer the remaining contents of the old bottle into the new one.

Mainly I wanted to try printing something threaded without supports, and it worked well. A surprising number of bottles of this size seem to work with it.

I also printed it on a solidoodle. You definitely don't want to have supports enabled regardless of the printer you use.

Switch mounts below the power supply on the clone A8 printers. It uses 2 holes already in the power supply and hardware left over from the Kit. Measure your switch and adjust the hole accordingly.

Switch is wired in line with the red power wire. This way you can plug the printer in, but wait to power it on until voltages have stabilized. Less shock on the electronics that way.

description.text:
This is not my scan nor my model. I found this 3D model on myminfactory from "Scan The World". It prints out great and i thought I would share it here on thingiverse.

The original link is below.

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/thuner-saxon-god-of-thunder-v-a-sculpture-gallery-london-1797

Info From Wiki about statue.

Thuner, the god of thunder, is one of the seven Saxon gods, each representing a day of the week. It was carved circa 1730 for Sir Richard Temple, Viscount Cobham (1675-1749) for his garden in Stowe, Buckinghamshire. On the base of the sculpture, Thuner's name is carved in runes beneath a thunderbolt. Originally the statues were set around an altar in an open grove, known as the Saxon Temple at Stowe; later they were placed in Stowe's Gothic Temple of Liberty. They formed part of an important group of buildings and statuary erected by Lord Cobham during the 1730s, which embodied a political programme championing Whig beliefs in historic British liberty.

Rysbrack was one of the most important sculptors working Britain at this time. A native of the Netherlands, he came over to England in about 1720, and soon established himself as a sculptor of monuments, portraits and busts. The Saxon gods, however, are unique in his work; neither are similar figures known by any other sculptors.

One of the things that I'm constantly wishing I had more of are coat hooks!  I have way too many hoodies and I hate leaving them on the floor.  So here's my take on a coat hook.  The special feature of this one is that it has 2 hooks for optimum hanging excellence.
The design was a mashup of qcad and openscad.  i just couldn't get the curves quite right in openscad and I wanted something with both an angular and curved look.
"If we don't all hang together, then surely, we shall all hang separately."
-Benjamin Franklin
(get it, there are two hooks for hanging...) :X
Print, screw into wall, hang coats!

description.text:
A simple filament cleaner/lubricator to help with your 3d printer.

I've seen many designs, but decided to make my own. Self-sufficiency is key!

Print 2 of these, cut some sponge to go in the alcoves. ~A spot of oil on the sponges helps with lubrication~, then attach around your filament with zip ties (just above the extruder)

Voila! Less dirt, and less extruder stepper skipping!

Although designed with 1.75mm filament in mind, I have better experience scaling to 115% before printing :/

Lubrication is a BAD idea, I discovered. Although it appears to stop extruder stepper skipping, the oil clogs up in the throat of the hot end, and I ended up with a severe blockage of burnt oil, and PLA that had "gone weird". It took about 45 minutes to unclear that mess, so I will not be using oil again! Plain sponge does still help keep foreign matter out of the hot-end, so it is still a net-win to use this (or something similar)

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3 clone

No

No

0.2

25%

Notes:

description.text: The Assault Frigate Mk. II was a further development of the Dreadnaught-class heavy cruiser modification project, which produced the Mark I Assault Frigate. title: Peacefair PZEM-051 Volt/Am meter enclosure
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is the enclosure for the Peacefair brand Voltmeter/Ammeter with shunt. Can be placed either horizontally or vertically.

Print with 20%, support is optional.

Product type: PZEM-051

Product Description of the PZEM-051

  1. Electrical parameter measurement function (voltage, current, active power, energy)
  2. Voltage alarm function (over voltage alarm threshold, backlight and voltage flashing to alarm).
  3. The reset/function button.
  4. Store data when power off.
  5. Large-screen LCD (display voltage, current, active power, energy at the same time)

  6. Backlight function.

  7. Power: test range: 0~10kW
    within 1KW, the display format is 0.0~999.9W;
    1KW and above, the display format is 1000~9999W.
  8. Energy: test range: 0~9999kWh
    Within 10KWh, the display format is 0~9999Wh;
    10kWh and above, the display format is 10~9999kWh.
  9. Voltage: test range: 6.5~100V
    Display format: 6.50~99.99V
  10. Current: test range: 0~100A
    Display format: 0.00~99.99

print_settings.Notes:: The FDL-2 in the pictures is printed at a .2mm layer height with 20% infill. Support isn't required but a wide brim is recommended for tall parts or parts without a lot of surface area touching the bed. All parts have been oriented how they should print best but feel free to arrange and orient them however. You shouldn't need to do much post print finishing aside from some minor cleanup. The holes in the barrel to attach the motors and the ones in the barrel cap need to be drilled out. The "counterbores" face up so it's cleaner to print a couple layers of bridging across them rather than circles in mid air. Each of the receiving screw holes should be tapped to accept the machine screws. #6 wood screws would probably work but I personally prefer tapping.

title: FDL-2 Blaster
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The FDL-2 is the successor to the FDL-1 Robotic Foam Dart Lancher. It is similar in function but instead of "Mega" sized darts firing from a revolver, it is designed to accept Nerf brand magazines and Nerf "Elite" size darts. It is fully automatic with an adjustable rate of fire up to about 8 darts per second. It also has select fire allowing you to fire in bursts of 1, 2, or 3 shots in addition to full auto. The entire FDL-2 is controlled by a Particle Photon microcontroller. The Photon is very similar to an Arduino except it has built in wifi allowing you to flash new code to it without plugging a USB cable into it. Darts are propelled by brushless outrunner motors which are powered by electronic speed controllers (ESC's). The FDL-2 uses a stepper motor based pusher mechanism to push darts between the flywheels. Between the microcontroller, stepper motor, and speed controllers the FDL-2 has a limitless set of tuning options. The entire blaster can be reprogrammed to operate in any way. Having wifi also opens up the possibility of using a phone app or web page to fine tune the function of the blaster on the fly.

Please visit projectfdl.com for more info. I have a web shop there selling assembled blasters, kits, electronics bundles, and bare pcb's to pair with your printed shell. If you just want to print an FDL-2 shell and not worry about soldering and sourcing parts, the electronics bundle is ideal for you. I provide everything you need to easily work into your print and finish off your blaster. I will preflash your Photon and test the entire bundle as a whole to ensure it works properly before you get it.


FDL-2 Introduction Video (Full drum firing demo at 20:15)


FDL-2 Blaster Assembly Part 1


FDL-2 Blaster Assembly Part 2


There are three different versions of the FDL-2. The original stepper motor version, the 2+, and the 2X.

If you are building an FDL-2+ print all the files in this thing and the 2+ remix:

FDL-2+ Blaster Remix

If you are building an FDL-2X print all the files in this thing and the 2X remix:

FDL-2X Blaster Remix

If you are building an original stepper motor FDL-2 print all the files in this thing but use the versions in the stepper motor remix instead. Then print all the parts in the 2+ remix.

FDL-2 Original Stepper Version Remix

Requires a 3S LiPo battery with an XT60 connector capable of safely delivering at least 25amps for a sustained period. An example being a 1000mAh battery with a 25C constant discharge rate. 1000 * 25 / 1000 = 25amps rating. It must also be able to fit inside the grip of the blaster in a cavity measuring 24mm x 36mm x 94mm.

The holes in the barrel to attach the motors and the ones in the barrel cap need to be drilled out. The "counterbores" face up so it's cleaner to print a couple layers of bridging across them rather than circles in mid air. Each of the receiving screw holes should be tapped to accept the machine screws. #6 wood screws would probably work but I personally prefer tapping.

The side panels are pretty long and the magwell is tall. I would check those two first. If you are intending on building this from scratch you're looking at a project roughly equivalent to building a drone or rc car from scratch. You need to be able to do somewhat delicate PCB soldering and wiring harness/loom soldering as well as heat shrinking. The people who have built these from scratch have either not needed to ask me questions or were good after a couple minor clarifications. If you have a lot of questions looking through this page and the other Project FDL resources, you may want to consider having me put an electronics bundle together for you. comments.text: Heh, I was wondering if anyone would notice that. I made a couple of those for "NIC" wars which are a more "no holds barred" version of the average Nerf war. We make our own darts out of foam backer rod, hot glue, and bb's and all the blasters are designed to fire at paintball velocities. That was my first attempt at making a blaster like that. The plunger head and catch are printed as well as the grip and pull back handle. The main body is just a pvc pipe with a reducer on the end that the barrel attaches to. Inside is the heaviest spring I could find in my local hardware store. I'm tempted to post the design here but there are a million better designs on nerfhaven.com.
comments.author: tuckem

comments.text: thanks for your reply....can you tell me about your trigger..may be a picture?
comments.author: JesseKovarovics

comments.text: It's a very simple trigger with a piece that extends forward an inch or two with a triangular shape on the end that reaches into the plunger tube trough a dremeled slot. The plunger has a rim around it that the triangular piece catches on to until you pull the trigger. It's not the best design at all but allowed me to use a threaded rod as the plunger rod. The better way is to create a rainbow type catch. You'd cut a slot in the plunger rod, usually a square delrin rod, and have a catch piece with a spring that pushes the catch into the slot when the plunger is pulled bach. Pulling the trigger pushes the catch up and out of the slot and allows the plunger to move forward.

I wouldn't recommend trying to print flywheels unless they mount like these do or you will have trouble getting them balanced and keeping them from wondering off the shaft of the motor. comments.text:
Hi Lylle,
I'll have a parts list up in the next couple weeks as well as an assembly video like I did with the FDL-1. The FDL-2 is designed around Multistar Elite 2300kv motors like the FDL-1. The new ESC's on the FDL-2 are 12amp Afro's w/ BEC. That's just a motor/ESC combo I know works but others would too. The flywheels are designed to fit onto the Multistars though. There is a wiring diagram in amongst the pictures up above that should help. The lipo connects to the ESC's. The ESC's power the Photon. The switch is connected to the Photon.
comments.author: lyellread

comments.text:
Thanks for the reply. those items look great and are reasonably cheap. Do you of any way of using the ESC's without the photon or another board in the gun? I have done some mild research and nothing turned up. My thought would be to put the positive of the LiPo through a microswitch and then into the ESC with it always "on" so the motors fire up on a button press, but there is no board in the gun. Thanks a bunch!!
Lyell
comments.author: JesseKovarovics

comments.text: I'm not sure you can send just a constant voltage to it. I may be wrong, I've just never honestly tried it. Using a microcontroller of some sort is really just the best way to go. Running your motors at full speed won't always get you the best performance. There's a sweet spot that you need to find where you're not losing so much to dart slippage. Your maximum accuracy may be at half that. The cost and space a small microcontroller would take up well exceeds the advantages it provides, even if you have to write some code to make it happen.
comments.author: lyellread

comments.text: Hi, awesome project by the way. I'm more of a rc guy and the first thing i thought of is your spull up and down time si really long, have you tough about using the OneShot125 functionality that afro esc-s should have. It is basically a active brake system so your motos stop really fast. I have LDPOWER D250-2 that has oneshot125 on my quad and the motors stop with propellers attached from a max rpm to dead stop in about half a second or faster.
comments.author: JesseKovarovics

comments.text: Thanks! As far as I know OneShot125 is a BLheli feature and it requires communication with the flight controller that I don't quite know how to do with a Photon quite yet. These are SimonK. I tried a pair of DYS ESCs at one point that had BLHeli and while they did spin up faster, there was just enough of a lag before it happened that it kinda cancelled out the quick spinup. It was even more pronounced with braking on. With a single fire button it's crucial that the user feels something happen immediately when they press the trigger. I'd like to try a pair of KISS ESCs at some point but right now their cost is too high to put into the kit. I'll try the BLHeli ESCs again though. Maybe I was missing a setting somewhere.

print_settings.Notes:: You can see the right antenna (left side of the photo) dish came out a bit smoother, I think that's because I had it oriented flat (up) in the print, the other was oriented at a slight angle.

description.text:
Everybody will know you're an alien if you have stalks sticking out of your head with little dishes on the end.

There's a left and a right antenna, but they're just symmetric mirrors of each other. The .stl files are about 6.5" tall, you can scale them as desired. I'm also including the .blend file incase you want to tweak / remix.

As for where you attach these antennae, or how - I'm leaving that up to the end user... could be glued into a wig, or more likely attached to a headband. You might also drill holes near the flat circle and pass through an elastic strap, though I think the strap would have to be rather tight, and you might want to scale the flat circles to be a bit bigger if you're going that way. The ~1.7" diameter flat circle is intended to go flat on your body, with the more cosmetic dimple-dish showing to the world. If you must 3D print the whole thing, you can mix this design with something like http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:242087 or http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:521515 or draw your own extruded arc to attach these to. Personally, I think using a commercial off-the-shelf headband makes a lot of sense.

I know that antennae and ears have http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1822443 been http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:34064 done http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:32887 before http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:174949 . Hopefully, these are a new/unique enough style to be interesting for some people who might want to use them in a costume. Antennae are simple, lightweight costume accessories with a lot of visual impact.

Printer:

FlashForge Dreamer

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.18mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I just went with standard print settings. I don't usually print with rafts/supports, but this design needs it - I had bad luck first try with 2mm tree-like supports. The next two prints with 3mm tree-like supports went fine.

You can see the right antenna (left side of the photo) dish came out a bit smoother, I think that's because I had it oriented flat (up) in the print, the other was oriented at a slight angle.

Cleanup

The support pattern will make your alien look like he's got a rash behind the antennae dishes unless you do a little cleanup. Personally, I think matte is a good finish for these, so I'm just sanding my ABS prints, not doing any polishing.

Blender - Skins

The basic shape is a segmented linear edge, with three points at each joint. I "skinned" the edge, smoothed it to the "3" level, shrunk all of it, then re-enlarged at the middle of each 3 points to make the joint appearance. The attachment disc is another enlargement, but the dish is a bisected sphere, given a little thickness and set down over the segmented edge - the reverse-dimple in the middle of the dish is the end of the edge.

I didn't know how to do skinning, or bisection when I started this, earlier today. Blender has plenty of good tutorials on the web.

author: Vetto77

description.text:
The Meissner Tetrahedron is a body of constant width.
That means, you can use it to roll a plane on it like on a ball, and the distance keeps the same.
From the look of the somewhat irregular shape you might think that would be a bumpy ride, but it ist not! Here's a nice explanation on those bodies:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cUCSSJwO3GU

comments.text: Hi, how did you modify the reuleaux tetrahedron to make this meissner tetrahedron? Obviously you have curved the 3 edges, but what is the radius of those curved edges? is it just curved so that it's smooth to the sides, or is the radius of the curved sections the same radius as the sides of the tetrahedron (reuleaux or meissner)?
comments.author: Gregregorovich

comments.text: The edges opposite of each sharp edge have to be rounded. It's a variable radius. As you can see, it gets sharp to the corners. You connect the corners with a staight line, then project the line on the spherical surface to one side, and rotate the projected curve around the line. That's how it did it :-)

title: Bird Viking themed light switch plate with or without Key Racks

description.text:
How I printed:

In CURA
1 turn off enable retraction option
2 Fill density 100%
3 print speed 45 (mm/s)
4 print temperature 180

My printer is RepRap from the MOST Athena Printer http://www.appropedia.org/Athena_Build_Overview

I use PLA red 1.75mm ( the real diameter is 1.94 mm)

How I create:

I download the bird image from https://s-media-cache-ak0.pinimg.com/236x/ae/04/71/ae0471d53045c767e89caaee65ae0d2f.jpg.

I use Inkscape to convert 2D cat image to generate path to openSCAD.

I use openSCAD to design light switch plate with Key Racks. I open cat.SCAD file in openSCAD and then copied all the code and pasted them into my light switch plate with Key Racks.

I use Inkscape to convert 2D image to generate path to openSCAD.

The problem is installing the software.
My laptop is Mac.
I downloaded the Inkscape software from https://inkscape.org/en/learn/books/

I need to download XQuartz software from https://www.xquartz.org/

To use the function OpenSCAD converter from Inkscape, I need to add these two files into Inkscape extension folder from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:25036

In Mac, these files are hidden. I need to use terminal to find these files and then move them to Inkscape folder by using these commands.

mv paths2openscad.py ~/.config/inkscape/extensions/

mv paths2openscad.inx ~/.config/inkscape/extensions/

author: electrifying-ideas

title: davinci xyz printer extruder main fan housing upgrade

description.text:
a better stock cooling solution
there is no reason to put a second fan on because the stock fan is sufficient if the bracket was designed properly
this is the design that should have ben on the DA vinci
if you look at the image of the stock fan mount you will see that it just blows straight against the top of the tube and not on the heat block and it is open on the sides so it blows straight and hits the other side and bounces straight back to just blow the same air out the sides of the fan

this design blows directly on the cooling fins and block and since it is facing more down than straight it blows it down around the heating block and blowing the heat onto the bed helping keep the upper layers of your design heated to allow better adhesion to the layers where other people are making fan housings and adding extra fans

by adding a fan to blow on the heat block you are cooling the fillament as it is coming out of the tip so the layers will not adhere as well
people are doing it but i think it is a bad idea all around to use a second fan like that

this solves all of the cooling problems of xyz printing head issues

comments.text: Hi caj,
comments.author: nestyr

comments.text: it works pretty good the main reason for me making this was because of filament over heating in the tube and jamming this cools redirects the air around the fins keeping the tube cool the added benefit was the better prints i used to have ABS lay down with no adheasion between layers now all my prints are smooth and solid amazing what one little change can make the bad thing is with my upgrade to print at higher temps around 300c my fan cooling is to efeciant and i have to turn the fan facing the the other direction  because it will not let me get above 270c
comments.author: caj

comments.text: Wow it is amazing how much difference this makes I kept trying to print PLA with my davinci 1.0a but it kept jamming after a few minutes so i added a few small heatsinks and this fan adapter and it worked like a charm great work! now i am printing PLA i also added the fan adapter on the side of the printer cover

remixed_from.author: sreisig1
remixed_from.title: Demon Baby Halloween Prop Costume FIXED

description.text:
Wondering what my halloween costume would be i looked around for a couple days...
Thanks to sreisig1 and Taikonaught's cool work I saw the demon baby and inmediately decided that an alien/demon being/baby spouting from my manly belly would be awesome... but wee needed a tad bit more...I decided that the baby needed to wake up on command.. and when it did.. you'd be sorry you woke him.

Used a digispark and a couple leds, rgbs, drilled some holes in the eyes and the back of the hands, and inserted the pwm controlled leds to generate the awakening. Then I wrote out a very simple arduino program based on the fade example to control these. My test subjects were my wife and 7 year old who really liked it..and my 4 year old who is unconfortable around it... which makes it just creepy enough for a family halloween trick or treat

here is what it looks like lit up. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-8QL3KXgu6A

Happy Halloween

author: electrifying-ideas

title: Fox  Viking themed light switch plate

description.text:
The wall plate size may be smaller than the real light switch wall plate. You can go to Two Fox Viking themed light switch plate from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1833561 for the bigger wall plate.

How I printed:

In CURA
1 turn off enable retraction option
2 Fill density 100%
3 print speed 45 (mm/s)
4 print temperature 180

My printer is RepRap from the MOST Athena Printer http://www.appropedia.org/Athena_Build_Overview

I use PLA red 1.75mm ( the real diameter is 1.94 mm)

How I create the model:

I download the fox image from https://s-media-cache-ak0.pinimg.com/originals/46/34/60/4634602d5f438f4ff0c5290c86a8d25a.png

I use Inkscape to convert 2D cat image to generate path to openSCAD.

I use openSCAD to design light switch plate with Key Racks. I open cat.SCAD file in openSCAD and then copied all the code and pasted them into my light switch plate with Key Racks.

I use Inkscape to convert 2D image to generate path to openSCAD.

The problem is installing the software.
My laptop is Mac.
I downloaded the Inkscape software from https://inkscape.org/en/learn/books/

I need to download XQuartz software from https://www.xquartz.org/

To use the function OpenSCAD converter from Inkscape, I need to add these two files into Inkscape extension folder from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:25036

In Mac, these files are hidden. I need to use terminal to find these files and then move them to Inkscape folder by using these commands.

mv paths2openscad.py ~/.config/inkscape/extensions/

mv paths2openscad.inx ~/.config/inkscape/extensions/

author: snuchitp

print_settings.Notes:: View parts list in images for other data.

description.text:
This is an automatic turning platform for 3D scanning with a cellphone. The platform turns the cellphone along a 380mm diameter circle. The turning mechanism is activated by a servo controlled by an Arduino board in a specific sequence which makes pauses to activate the cellphone camera with the Bluetooth remote control. The servo tower can be easily removed to activate the turning mechanism manually with the handle.
The platform is too big to be printed one shot. One of my goal with this design was not to use any glue or screw… only 3D printing (except for attaching the electronics to the platform) . Therefore, I developed different kinds of snaps and shapes to attach parts together.

Electronic parts:
-Arduino UNO R3 (M.Jduino UNO r3)
-YwRobot Relay
-Generic Bluetooth smartphone selfy remote control
-TowerPro Micro Servo 9g. (I converted the servo to be able to do a continuous turning )

You can find the parts list which includes the parts data such as printing time, estimated filament and price and number of pieces needed. The numbers of the pieces are referenced in the 3D render images of separate parts.
You can also find the code in the txt file.

Here is a video of it in action and the result model. :)
https://youtu.be/3Wq3vU6Ea6A

Enjoy

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa I3

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15%

Notes:

View parts list in images for other data.

Assembly experiance

I have tested each snap and assembly on partial prints and they all worked fine. When printing bigger peaces it changes the temperature and therefore the prints are not exactly as the one tested. Therefore i had to file some of the round snap knobs (the long ones) to prevent them from breaking when snapping them with other parts.
When assembling the top ring, putting the snaps together only rigidify when both sides are snapped correctly. Althow i did'nt want to use any glue, i chickened out on that top ring and put glue in the snap holes before inserting the small "C" clamps.

If some turning parts are to snuggled, you can put just a tini bit of Jig-a-loo and turn the parts to spread and dry it.

description.text:
This thing includes two different styles of pins, one being rounded and the other being angled.  
A geoboard is a mathematical manipulative used to explore basic concepts in plane geometry such as perimeter, area and the characteristics of triangles and other polygons. It consists of a physical board with a certain number of pegs, around which are wrapped rubber bands. (Wikipedia)  
Being one of my favorite manipulative learning objects when I was younger, I had to submit it.

comments.text: I tried printing geoboard2.stl. The lettering extends below the bottom face by a little bit, which is not ideal as the entire base then needs to be printed on a raft. Plus, the pegs are very thin, making them prone to snapping off or getting bent while printing. Making them a bit thicker as in the photo would be better.

title: Bouchon de trappe de coque arr avec ventilation pour stackage

description.text:
Voici un bouchon de trappe de visite pour le trimaran weta qui sert lorsqu'il est a terre pour ventiler la coque.

J'ai remarqué que lorsque que le weta reste a terre pendant une ou deux semaine dehors sous bâche, il y a toujours un peut d'eau dans les petites coques, sans doute la condensation.
Après, su ont laisse les bouchons des trappes de visite ouvert, le joint est parfoit au soleil, se qui n'est pas bon.

Là, il suffit d'ouvrir les trappes d'origine, puis mettre ceux là en place a la place.
J'ai mis une garcette sur le bouchon remplaçant pour être sur de le voir et ne pas l'oublier lorsque je vais a l'eau...

author: knight77520

title: Prusa Z axis, so many problems yet one simple solution !

description.text:
Note: This has worked perfectly for more than a year and is still valid. BUT, I wanted to go further and get rid of all the crappy linear bearings and poor leadscrew nuts. Done, I even managed to get rid of the vertical smooth rods, the lead screws can do the job (although TR10 would be more rigid, TR8 are acceptable) see here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2594693

WARNING:
Don't be misled by the negative comments found here. This WORKS ! Unfortunately some people either misunderstand or simply lack the proper knowledge to understand, others are just expressing their anger for my critics of their poor, flawed "things". Just check what these people published and demonstrated. Some even created accounts, nothing published, just to spit their hatred. Amusing :)

PS: Beware, some are crooks, as they tried to call for funding or sell their wares I shot down ! See the first posts below for such piece of human garbage !

+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

The Prusa configuration is one of the most common, low cost, easy to build 3D printer, yet it has a few flaws and limitation but one that is not acceptable as it is easy to fix, two unsynchronized steppers driving a lead screw at each end of the X carriage. To make things worse, many kits are supplied with regular M5 or M8 threaded rod totally unsuitable for the task ( even often bent !).

You can find a myriad of poor attempts to get rid of the wobble and canted X carriage. Plastic braces to try to constrain the lead screw are just reducing it, not eliminating it.
Auto bed leveling gimmicks are just a waste, often introducing more problems ! And it adds weight (except the IR one from DC42 about the only decent one for the job) ! Note that auto bed leveling almost a must in a non Cartesian machine, is here a poor attempt at compensating a poorly designed, poorly assembled machine with dirt cheap poor quality components ! Better spend your time and money for real solutions.

Of course, what I propose is not the first set up making use of one motor, two screws with a closed belt and pulleys to drive them but is the simplest I have seen for a Prusa while allowing to tension the belt despite no idler pulley is used (can't make it simpler :) !)

It is designed for the Geetech Prusa Aluminum but can be adapted to many similar design. I arranged for the belt to be 760mm which is quite easy to find. You can make your own. I did it but it is a bit tricky to explain and do to get an almost professional splice.Here are links giving acceptable results to do it:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1814419
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2162222

Yes, you have to buy two TR8 either 8mm or 2mm lead with nuts, three pulleys but you will save one motor, two couplings (most are so bad you can throw them away) and plenty of headaches and time ! Refuse them if they come bent !

Initially I used ball bearings but switched to Igus bushings I printed (see my other things).

You could even use bronze or delrin bushings reused from old motor, printers ... The ID is 8, OD 12, h 6.. A very common size but for the h, not a big deal if you can use a hacksaw and a file !
Or even print them with PLA, ABS, PETG but how long will they last ?

Although I do not recommend it, if you plan to use ball bearings (needs to make new plate to fit them), keep in mind that as the leadscrew is the moving part it has to be "loctited" to the bearing inner race. Make sure to provide clearance where required too.

The left and right plates holding the bushings are identical and snap in place on top of the Geeetech top plate. Make sure the smooth rod is about 4 - 5 mm higher to go through the plate with a snug fit.

The plates could be secured by screws or even glued to the aluminum plate underneath but not required in my case as the 8mm guide rods and frame hold them thigh. In addition the belt tension takes up minute play.

The bushing is 1mm above the plate and the pulley rest on it. Igus plastic is fine against Al.

To adjust the belt tension, you just slide the motor holder and secure it with two screws (here I used Nylon M4 but any M4 or similar self tapping screws will do). Just a moderate tension is enough to remove all slack, it doesn't need to be as tight as for the X or Y axis.
Adjust the motor pulley height for proper belt alignment.

I use a 8mm lead screw and three 36 teeth pulleys giving 400 microsteps/mm, 0.04mm per full step, a number I like. As is, the required torque to go up is about 10 N.cm. No big deal for the Nema17 40mm.

I have used it for months now. It is proven solution. It should be easy to adapt to other "metal" Prusa variations. I don't recommend it for "acrylic" or other flimsy frames, these may bend with the belt tension unless reinforced and anyway are junks not worth improving. Sell or give them to people you don't like :)

No wobble, vibration (all my bearings are of my own BTW) and no need to level the bed anymore unless I make change to the bed for ex.
Now I can print decent parts and why not for a more professional design than the Prusa.

I added a version of motor bracket to be able to mount a PM 48 series stepper one can find in many laser printers. You may need an 3mm ID 5mm OD adapter. Torque is plenty enough for a regular Prusa provided there is no binding or the X carriage doesn't weight like a dead donkey.

Note that I reinforced the frame as you can see in the picture. Just two Aluminum profiles, bent plate and bolts, attached to the vertical frame and the M10 threaded rods. Many ways to do it, here are some decent solutions. Must be rigid, avoid flimsy plastic parts, makes them beefy. Then you can bolt the whole printer to a heavy thick (40mm) flat piece of old kitchen table top or anything like that.

  • I even simplified the system by removing the right rod: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2504861.

Simple, effective as it should be, properly constrained as per theory and proven in practice.

comments.text:
Dual z motors getting 'out of sync' is hardly an issue in our typical Prusa style machine. Yes when power is removed steppers do 'snap' to the nearest full step. Two motors driven from the same driver in series or parallel will always be at the same micro step as this is a function of the driver, not motor. So being at the same portion of a full step, both motors in all probability will 'snap' back to the same location. Even if they did not, we are talking at most half of one step out which is typically less than one degree of rotation in a lead screw which is significantly lower than the resolution in your typical x and y axis. During a print, the likelyhood of one z stepper missing a full step would be about as likely as any other stepper - how often do you notice this happening on x and y where it is much more obvious?
Additionally, in this day of auto leveling, any z axis misalignment between steppers would be cancelled out.
comments.author: jimovonz

comments.text: dual z motors do get out of sync with threaded smooth rods over time. If you are printing frequently you do need to keep them in sync but with one motor only not two. Even if you use auto leveling, you are hiding other issues aswell as possibility of binding the two z rods/extrusions over time.
comments.author: jimovonz

But that said even with a well set up machine Auto levelling can still help to remove any inconsistencies and make life easier when swapping out nozzles, changing bed surfaces etc.. which might induce small changes that can be catered for with an initial auto levelling routine.

Auto bed leveling is a 'fix' for failings that should otherwise be fixable with sufficient knowledge, resources and ability. first of all: my english isnt that good...
Iam a more or less good creator of 3D-arts and animations and i wanted to print some of my models, here we have Lola from Spacejam. To print her you need alot support, in fact the support needs more material than the figure self.
The support around her ears is very difficult, i made on my first lola not enough supports so the eartips didnt hold there and on secound time i made too much support that i ripped the eartip and the hand off as i tryed to remove it.

Ive printet her at 150% size with 80mm/sec, 2 outlines and 20% infill in around 6 hours.

The Model was created by Shadowsquirrel and rigged by a want-to-be-anonymous-friend

author: Luke321

title: Alternative Acrylic Electronics Mount Plate Brackets

description.text:
This mounting bracket is a derivative of Lulzbot's printed mounting bracket for their acrylic electronics mount plate. 
With this mounting bracket, half as many vitamins are necessary for mounting the acrylic plate. Also, it has a nut capture for easier assembly.
This design is also partially based on Brook's Printrbot y-bar mounts.

Print x4 of the brackets.
Place size #6-32 lock nuts inside each of the nut captures.
Use a 4x 1" long #6-32 screws if the acrylic plate is 1/8" thick, or 1.25" long screws for a 1/4" acrylic plate.

title: GoPro Hero 5 Session and GoPro Hero 4 Session Superview Mount 30° for Zmr250, Alien 5", QAV-R, Warp quad, whatever

description.text:
After some weeks of refinements and development I finally made my own GoPro Hero 4 & 5 mount.
The camera can record in superview without any visable mount parts in video.
All buttons, interfaces and the display is fully accessable.

Print in TPA with 20% Fill and 0.4-0.8mm wall thickness.
Use a fine nozzle to save weight.
Mine is about 14gr with a 0.4mm nozzle.
If you use a 0.1mm nozzle you can bring this down to 10gr. - I guess-

I am selling this on ebay:
http://www.ebay.de/itm/252549492191?ssPageName=STRK:MESELX:IT&_trksid=p3984.m1558.l2649

Here is my channel and a video with my session 4 and a early version of this mount:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eemj3hCYuxI

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,1 or 0,4mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Successfull printed with a Ultimaker 2+

PLEASE DO A QUICK TESTPRINT WITH YOUR PRINTER IF YOU ARE NOT USING A ULTIMAKER 2+. Things will come out smaller or bigger on other printers.

Print in TPA with 20% Fill and 6mm Wall Thickness.
Use a fine nozzle to save weight.
Mine is about 14gr. If you use a 0.1mm nozzle you can bring this down to 10gr.

please share your builds an toughts in the comments section

Use a very sharp knife to get rid of the support material.
Its a pain to clean this up so take your time.

These were one of my favorite math manipulatives when I first started working with fractions back in the day.  The tray makes this something that stores well, and the blocks are all numbered by size.  
Source files for the whole project as well as each piece individually are included for you to print as you like!  
Edit: I uploaded a new "1" fraction block where the direction of the number matches all the other blocks... print whichever you like!

Put together in Tinkercad... the poor man's cad solution :)  
These can be printed separately into whatever combination you like.  My wife teaches 3rd grade and they are always looking for these in 2nd and 3rd grade so I figured it couldn't hurt to have some for ourselves.  
I guesstimated some depths of numbers because we don't have a 3D printer to test it out.  If someone gets the hankering to print the largest and smallest, and then wants to give me some feedback on if I need to change the text sizes/depths - I'll update the files happily!

description.text:
Educational tool for blind children with the shape of the orion constellation. Also we have added braille in english.

For more visit the our website feelform.eu or facebook.com/feelform3D

Feelform is a initiative supported by the angelopoulos CGIU.

We design and 3D print innovative products for the blind. We design and 3D print innovative products for the blind. Our goal in Feelform is to stop the exclusion of the visually impaired from public space and provide the means for equality in education.

Orion educational material for the blind. A tactile representation of the Orion constellation, in order to allow blind children and adults realize the shape of the biggest stars of Orion.
How to use Always present it to the student in the proper direction. Explain the stars and the mental lines. Make sure your student understands the difference of the stars and mental lines.
Materials Nothing besides a printed item
15 to 30 minutes

description.text:
Tripod mount for gopro. Uses the clip that comes on the housing of gopro cameras. So you just mount the printed clip to the tripod and then you can hot-swap GoPros.

Requires a M5 nut which your heat and then squeeze into the slightly too small hex hole. I find heating the nut over your soldering iron as per the included images works well.

Also included an stl for a mount without the nut hole so you can just use this as a normal mount and add adhesive to the bottom as per the mounts that ship with GoPros.

description.text:
Ce principe permet de bloquer le stick (sans trop de force afin qu'il soit toujours possible de donner un coup de barre en cas de besoin).

Sur le Weta, je n'utilise plus le stick d'origine, mais un stick Viadana qui est télescopique.
Je n'ai pas encore testé avec le stick d'origine

author: Microdure

description.text:
A desktop stand for the Raspberry Pi Camera.

Features an enclosed case to keep out dust and a path for the camera's FFC to run under the stand and out the back.

Optional cork base to protect the FFC underneath.

Print with your favourite thermo-plastic (http://e3d-online.com/All-Filament)

Required Components.

1 x Raspberry Pi Camera.
1 x Long Raspberry Pi Camera FFC.
4 x M2 6mm Socket Cap Screws.
4 x M3 25mm Socket Cap Screws.
2 x M3 30mm Socket Cap Screws.
6 x M3 Hex nuts.
Sticky Backed Cork Sheet.

    

Love 3D printing? Love T-Shirts?

Then you need to check out steps-per-mm.xyz!

It is loaded with a huge range of wearable Parts & Components.

Please help support my work here on Thingiverse and on Instructables by using the following affiliate links when making purchases. Thanks :)

eBay.com | eBay.co.uk | eBay.fr | Amazon.co.uk

E3D's BigBox

Rafts:

No

No

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

15%

Here's a free test to se how well your printer handles overhangs, stringing and printing small details.

The cube is 100x100mm and built out of 4mm rods, have that in mind when scaling (theoretical minimum is 10 times smaller with a 0.4 mm nozzle).

Designed in less than 30min so tell me if something needs improving.

author: piposant

description.text:
I made this set with Eureka 3D designn software.  This is an update of a previous version.  Improvements are sizing, the King is about 70mm tall.  I changed the topper of the King as the original was a little to small to print well.  I also improved some of the horiz angles to make all of the pieces print better.  And I made the Knight's neck a little bigger at the base and taper up to give it a little more depth.  I think this is much better than the previous version and I've printed the entire set without any problem.  I've included separate files to print them logically.  The Knight requires support because of the chin overhang, but the rest of the set prints flawlessly without any supports at all.  
I also added the Eureka file (CGC) for the entire set so you can see how I made it if you have the Eureka Software, which I highly recommend.  Notice the file size difference between CGC and STL?  They're the EXACT same model.

I needed a stereo RCA to RCA adapter, It was Sunday, all shops closed, and I had spare connectors in my electronic parts box, so ... here it is, simple but efficient.
It may be improved a lot but it doesn't deserve the time required to.

Still a work in progress, only the first part is available.
I still have to make the top of the case, an enclosure for the Full Graphic screen,...

I have also included a file for a case for a DCDC converter cause I will be using a 24 volts PSU but I will be using 12 volt parts.
